 Today, again after adjusting for inflation, we are spending nine times as much on welfare as when the War on Poverty began in 1965. Last year we spent $324 billion on 78 different federal welfare programs. This was 5 percent of the gross national product. We are now spending more on welfare as a percentage of the Gross National Product than we were in the middle of the Great Depression in the 1930s, when a quarter of the labor force was unemployed. 
 
 The typical family of four in the United States today pays $2,000 every year in taxes to support the welfare state. If you're an upper-middle income family, it's closer to $6,000. As investors in the War on Poverty, as Lyndon Johnson called us, we're all sort of stockholders in the welfare state; I think we ought to have a stockholders meeting and see exactly what we've gotten for our $5 trillion investment. 
 
 ........
 What are the other consequences of the War on Poverty? Well, today, one out of every seven children in the United States is being raised on the Aid to Families With Dependent Children program, with Uncle Sam's welfare check serving as a surrogate father. Of those AFDC children, half will remain in the system for over 10 years. Even when they're off, they're likely to receive benefits from other welfare programs besides AFDC. 
 
 One of the key causes for this tremendous increase in welfare dependency in the last 30 years has been the rise in out-of-wedlock births. Back when the War on Poverty was starting, the percentage of children born out of wedlock was about 5 percent. Today it is over 30 percent. Three out of 10 children in the United States are born without a lawful father. If you look at Black communities, the out-of-wedlock birth rate went from about 25 percent up to an astonishing 68 percent. If you look at all other social indicators during this period, in particular violent crime, we find that as the War on Poverty kicks in and as we push more money into the system, the more violent crime we have, the more social, psychological and behavioral problems we seem to have. 
 
 As a stockholder in the War on Poverty, the typical tax-paying family of four can look forward to investing about $35,000 in the welfare state over the next 10 years. You can think what the opportunity costs of that investment are in terms of your own family. We ought to legitimately ask: After we each have put in our $35,000 over the next 10 years, will the well-being of American children be any better than it is today? The answer is no, it will almost certainly be significantly worse. Will our society be a better place to live in as a result of our $35,000 future investment in the War on Poverty? No, almost certainly it will be a worse place. Will dependency go down? Will we have fewer people on welfare? No, almost certainly not. We are likely to have a dramatic increase in welfare. 
 
 So maybe we ought to back up and ask the question, "Why does it seem that this enormous $5 trillion contribution has backfired? What was wrong with this investment?" If we can identify what was wrong with it, perhaps we can fix this system in the future. 
 
 
 What's gone wrong?
 
 The answer is that in welfare, as in most other things in life, you get what you pay for. Welfare pays for three things: non-work, divorce and illegitimacy, and we have achieved a dramatic increase in all three things in the last 30 years as a result of this system.
 
 Welfare insidiously creates its own clientele. The more that is spent under this current system, the more people will line up for services and the more people we have in need of aid. The effect of the system is far-reaching and penetrating, it actually removes the capacity of individuals to sustain themselves and their families; continuous welfare actually creates persons who cannot live without it. The more we spend, the more such individuals we create. We create multi-generations of individuals whose capacity for self-support has eroded and disappeared. 
 
 How is it that welfare has this sort of insidious effect? It's very simple. If you go to the core of the welfare system in the United States, we basically offer a young, unmarried woman with two children whom she has had out of wedlock a combined welfare benefits package of about $14,000 to $15,000 per year. We could call this her welfare paycheck. But there are two conditions that you, the taxpayer, insist on in order for her to be eligible to receive this $14,000- to $15,000-a-year welfare paycheck. 
 
 Condition No. 1: She cannot work. 
 Condition No. 2: She cannot marry an employed male. 
 If she does either of those things, her welfare benefits will be sharply cut or eliminated entirely. I call this the Incentive System from Hell. If you were to deliberately design a system that in the long term would have the maximum harmful impact on low-income Americans, this is the system you would devise. I often say to Black audiences that if David Duke wanted to think up a system to destroy Black communities in the United States, this is it. It's a system that explicitly penalizes work and explicitly penalizes marriage. But the problem from David Duke's perspective is that it's not just Black families that have been destroyed, it's been white families, as well.
 
 The negative effects of welfare have been confirmed over and over again in scientific experiments. Few people know that in the late 1970's, Daniel Patrick Moynihan put together a massive national experiment called the Seattle-Denver Income Maintenance Experiment. We spent many millions of dollars on a controlled experiment to evaluate the effects of welfare policy on human behavior.
 
 As far as I know, it was the largest controlled behavioral experiment in human history. In this experiment, we tested the effects of welfare scientifically, just as you would test the effects of a new drug. We took a population of potential welfare recipients and randomly divided them into a number of different groups. One group, called the control group, did not get any changes in welfare benefits. The other groups received different welfare packages with different benefit rates, phase-down rates and the like. There were many different types of packages, and we were able to evaluate their effects on human behavior by comparing the group that received these new benefits with the control group that was held at the status quo. 
 You have not heard of the Seattle-Denver Income Maintenance Experiment because the results were politically incorrect. This experiment showed, without any doubt, that the more money you give to a family on welfare, the less that family works and the more dependent they become on the system. The Seattle-Denver study showed, astonishingly, that for every additional $100 given to families in terms of increased monthly welfare benefits, those families on average over the course of the year reduced their labor force participation and earnings by $80. So for every one dollar you gave them, you had an 80-cent reduction in their own capacity, their own earnings, their own ability for self-support. That goes a long way in explaining how you can spend and spend and spend under this system and nothing seems to improve. The government cannot spend its way out of poverty, because all it ends up doing is replacing self-sufficiency with dependency.
 
 The experiment also showed that welfare has a profound tendency to splinter families -- to pull the husband out of the family, to make him irrelevant, and to increase the number of single-parent households. Similar studies that have been done -- not on a controlled experimental basis, but by comparing the effects of welfare among different states -- show that the intensiveness and the generosity of the welfare system has a dramatic effect on increasing the number of out-of-wedlock births, particularly among teenagers. Recent research by Dr. June O'Neill of Baruch College, in New York, has shown that if you increase the monthly welfare benefit package in the state by 50 percent, you will achieve a 40 percent increase in the number of out-of-wedlock births in the state. Again, that is one of the underlying factors in our problem of consistent poverty.
